title: Caveman/SLASH'EM
data:
|                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  |
| ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ |
| [ ]## Contents* [1 Starting equipment](#Starting_equipment)

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), the **Caveman** or **Cavewoman**, sometimes referred to as the **Caveperson**, is one of the [roles](/wiki/Role "Role") from *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")* that is available to the [hero](/wiki/Hero "Hero").

Cavepeople can be of [lawful](/wiki/Lawful "Lawful") or [neutral](/wiki/Neutral "Neutral") [alignment](/wiki/Alignment "Alignment"), and can be [humans](/wiki/Human_\(starting_race\) "Human (starting race)"), [dwarves](/wiki/Dwarf_\(starting_race\) "Dwarf (starting race)"), [gnomes](/wiki/Gnome_\(starting_race\) "Gnome (starting race)"), or [doppelgangers](/wiki/Doppelganger_\(starting_race\) "Doppelganger (starting race)").

## Starting equipment

Each Caveperson starts with the following equipment:[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

- a +1 [club](/wiki/Club "Club") ([wielded](/wiki/Wielded "Wielded"))
- a +2 [sling](/wiki/Sling "Sling") (alternate weapon)
- 10-22 [flint stones](/wiki/Flint_stone "Flint stone")[\[2\]](#cite_note-ammo-2)
- 18-33 uncursed [rocks](/wiki/Rock "Rock")[\[2\]](#cite_note-ammo-2)
- +0 [leather armor](/wiki/Leather_armor "Leather armor")

The Caveperson's default starting [pet](/wiki/Pet "Pet") is a [little dog](/wiki/Little_dog "Little dog") called Slasher.

## Intrinsics

Cavepeople gain the following intrinsic [properties](/wiki/Properties "Properties") upon reaching the given [experience levels](/wiki/Experience_level "Experience level"):[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)

- Level 7: [speed](/wiki/Speed "Speed")
- Level 15: [warning](/wiki/Warning "Warning")

## Attributes

The Caveperson's starting [attributes](/wiki/Attribute "Attribute") are distributed as follows:[\[4\]](#cite_note-4)

| Attributes                 | [Strength](/wiki/Strength "Strength") | [Dexterity](/wiki/Dexterity "Dexterity") | [Constitution](/wiki/Constitution "Constitution") | [Intelligence](/wiki/Intelligence "Intelligence") | [Wisdom](/wiki/Wisdom "Wisdom") | [Charisma](/wiki/Charisma "Charisma") | Remaining |
| -------------------------- | ------------------------------------- | ---------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------- | ------------------------------------- | --------- |
| Minimum attributes         | 10                                    | 7                                        | 8                                                 | 7                                                 | 7                               | 6                                     | 30        |
| Distribution percentages   | 30%                                   | 20%                                      | 30%                                               | 6%                                                | 7%                              | 7%                                    |           |
| Mean w/ standard deviation | 18/01.61±2.48                         | 13.19±2.16                               | 16.43±1.76                                        | 8.90±1.40                                         | 9.21±1.49                       | 7.90±1.40                             |           |

## Skills

Cavepeople have the following [skills](/wiki/Skill "Skill") available to them:[\[5\]](#cite_note-5)

| Barbarian skills |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      |
| ---------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ |
| Max              | [Skills](/wiki/Skill "Skill")                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        |
| Basic            | - *Weapons:* [dagger](/wiki/Dagger "Dagger"), [pick-axe](/wiki/Pick-axe "Pick-axe"), [morning star](/wiki/Morning_star "Morning star"), [unicorn horn](/wiki/Unicorn_horn "Unicorn horn")
- *Spells:* [enchantment spells](/wiki/Spellcasting_\(SLASH%27EM\)#Enchantment_spells "Spellcasting (SLASH'EM)")                                                                           |
| Skilled          | * *Weapons:* [knife](/wiki/Knife "Knife"), [axe](/wiki/Axe "Axe"), [flail](/wiki/Flail "Flail"), [hammer](/wiki/Hammer "Hammer"), [polearms](/wiki/Polearms "Polearms"), [javelin](/wiki/Javelin "Javelin"), [trident](/wiki/Trident "Trident"), [sling](/wiki/Sling "Sling")
* *Spells:* [matter spells](/wiki/Spellcasting_\(SLASH%27EM\)#Matter_spells "Spellcasting (SLASH'EM)") |
| Expert           | - *Weapons:* [club](/wiki/Club "Club"), [paddle](/wiki/Paddle "Paddle"), [mace](/wiki/Mace "Mace"), [quarterstaff](/wiki/Quarterstaff "Quarterstaff"), [spear](/wiki/Spear "Spear"), [bow](/wiki/Bow "Bow"), [boomerang](/wiki/Boomerang "Boomerang")                                                                                                                                |
| Master           | * *Combat:* [bare hands](/wiki/Bare_hands "Bare hands")                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              |

Cavepeople start with *Basic* skill in clubs, slings, and bare-handed combat. Their [special spell](/wiki/Special_spell "Special spell") is [dig](/wiki/Spellbook_of_dig "Spellbook of dig").

## Techniques

Cavepeople can learn the [disarm](/wiki/Disarm "Disarm") [technique](/wiki/Technique "Technique") by reaching Skilled in any weapon, and also gain the following techniques:[\[6\]](#cite_note-6)

|           |                                                |
| --------- | ---------------------------------------------- |
| **Level** | **Technique**                                  |
| 1         | [Primal roar](/wiki/Primal_roar "Primal roar") |

## Special rules

Cavepeople have a 2-square vision radius.[\[7\]](#cite_note-7)

Cavepeople do not suffer any penalty for [cannibalism](/wiki/Cannibalism "Cannibalism"), including the [aggravate monster](/wiki/Aggravate_monster "Aggravate monster") property given from eating [domestic](/wiki/Domestic "Domestic") [canine](/wiki/Canine "Canine") or [feline](/wiki/Feline "Feline") [corpses](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse"), and additionally gain a +1 bonus to [alignment record](/wiki/Alignment_record "Alignment record") each time they consume a [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") or [tin](/wiki/Tin "Tin") of their race.[\[8\]](#cite_note-8)

Cavepeople never get [nausea](/wiki/Nausea "Nausea") from eating [tripe rations](/wiki/Tripe_ration "Tripe ration").

## Rank titles

The [status line](/wiki/Status_line "Status line") displays one of the following ranks for the corresponding experience levels:[\[9\]](#cite_note-9)

- XL 1-2: Troglodyte
- XL 3-5: Aborigine
- XL 6-9: Wanderer
- XL 10-13: Vagrant
- XL 14-17: Wayfarer
- XL 18-21: Roamer
- XL 22-25: Nomad
- XL 26-29: Rover
- XL 30: Pioneer

## Quest

- *Main article: [Caveman quest](/wiki/Caveman_quest "Caveman quest")*

The Caveperson's [quest](/wiki/Quest "Quest") sees them fighting the [Chromatic Dragon](/wiki/Chromatic_Dragon "Chromatic Dragon") for [The Sceptre of Might](/wiki/The_Sceptre_of_Might "The Sceptre of Might"), an [artifact](/wiki/Artifact "Artifact") [mace](/wiki/Mace "Mace"). It has +3 [to-hit](/wiki/To-hit "To-hit") and deals +5 against monsters of a different [alignment](/wiki/Alignment "Alignment") from the artifact, and grants [magic resistance](/wiki/Magic_resistance "Magic resistance") while carried. [Invoking](/wiki/Invoking "Invoking") The Sceptre of Might toggles hungerless [conflict](/wiki/Conflict "Conflict") on or off, and conflict caused by the artifact ends once it leaves the main inventory.

## Gods

- *Main article: [Religion](/wiki/Religion "Religion")*

The Caveman pantheon is based on [the mythology of Mesopotamia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mesopotamian_mythology "wikipedia:Mesopotamian mythology") (sometimes known as Babylon).[\[10\]](#cite_note-10) Their first [sacrifice gift](/wiki/Sacrifice_gift "Sacrifice gift") is [Skullcrusher](/wiki/Skullcrusher "Skullcrusher").

- Lawful: [Anu](/wiki/Anu "Anu")
- Neutral: [Ishtar](/wiki/Ishtar "Ishtar")
- Chaotic: [Anshar](/wiki/Anshar "Anshar")

## Strategy

A user has suggested improving this page or section as follows:

*"Detail to match the layout of other NetHack/SLASH'EM role strategy sections and distinguish it from those."*

Cavepeople have a handful of additional benefits compared to their *NetHack* counterparts. Their natural 2-square vision range makes corridors and dark areas like the [Gnomish Mines](/wiki/Gnomish_Mines "Gnomish Mines") substantially safer to explore even without [infravision](/wiki/Infravision "Infravision"). The [primal roar](/wiki/Primal_roar "Primal roar") technique causes all nearby [pets](/wiki/Pet "Pet") to temporarily [grow up](/wiki/Grow_up "Grow up") (e.g. a [kitten](/wiki/Kitten "Kitten") becomes a [housecat](/wiki/Housecat "Housecat"), a [dog](/wiki/Dog "Dog") becomes a [large dog](/wiki/Large_dog "Large dog"), etc.), making it life-saving in the early game and a powerful option later on. Unfortunately, Cavepeople do not possess a [multishot](/wiki/Multishot "Multishot") bonus for [thrown](/wiki/Thrown "Thrown") [spears](/wiki/Spear "Spear") due to SLASH'EM being a variant of [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3"), since the multishot bonus was added in a later version—the Sceptre of Might is also much weaker as a long-term main weapon candidate, though it does not need to be wielded for magic resistance and invoking for conflict is still quite useful.

The starting flint stones can be [upgraded](/wiki/Upgraded "Upgraded") into [luckstones](/wiki/Luckstone "Luckstone") or [healthstones](/wiki/Healthstone "Healthstone"), which has the effect of making gnomish Cavepeople far less disadvantageous to play as: once they secure a source of reliable [permafood](/wiki/Permafood "Permafood"), they can use the race's [tinker](/wiki/Tinker "Tinker") technique in order to upgrade their flint stones. Cavepeople should try to obtain their first gift Skullcrusher as soon as possible: it has +3 to-hit and deals +10 damage to all monsters, allowing it to hold its own well into the late game. The primal roar technique is also especially strong for enterprising Cavepeople that manage to obtain rare pets such as [gnolls](/wiki/Gnoll_\(SLASH%27EM\) "Gnoll (SLASH'EM)") or [liches](/wiki/Lich_\(monster_class\) "Lich (monster class)").

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [u\_init.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 52](/wiki/Source:SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/u_init.c#line52 "Source:SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/u init.c")
2. ↑ [2.0](#cite_ref-ammo_2-0) [2.1](#cite_ref-ammo_2-1) [u\_init.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 1051](/wiki/Source:SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/u_init.c#line1051 "Source:SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/u init.c")
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) [attrib.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 39](/wiki/Source:SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/attrib.c#line39 "Source:SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/attrib.c")
4. [↑](#cite_ref-4) [role.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 107](/wiki/Source:SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/role.c#line107 "Source:SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/role.c"): *Cav attributes and distributions*
5. [↑](#cite_ref-5) [u\_init.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 1450](/wiki/Source:SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/u_init.c#line1450 "Source:SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/u init.c")
6. [↑](#cite_ref-6) [tech.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 90](/wiki/Source:SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/tech.c#line90 "Source:SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/tech.c")
7. [↑](#cite_ref-7) [u\_init.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 1050](/wiki/Source:SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/u_init.c#line1050 "Source:SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/u init.c")
8. [↑](#cite_ref-8) [eat.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 509](/wiki/Source:SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/eat.c#line509 "Source:SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/eat.c"): *"You honour the dead."*
9. [↑](#cite_ref-9) [role.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 86](/wiki/Source:SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/role.c#line86 "Source:SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/role.c")
10. [↑](#cite_ref-10) [role.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 96](/wiki/Source:SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/role.c#line96 "Source:SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/role.c")

Caveman/SLASH'EM

From NetHackWiki
< Caveman
Jump to navigation Jump to search

Contents

  • 1 Starting equipment
  • 2 Intrinsics
  • 3 Attributes
  • 4 Skills
  • 5 Techniques
  • 6 Special rules
  • 7 Rank titles
  • 8 Quest
  • 9 Gods
  • 10 Strategy
  • 11 References

In SLASH'EM, the Caveman or Cavewoman, sometimes referred to as the Caveperson, is one of the roles from NetHack that is available to the hero.

Cavepeople can be of lawful or neutral alignment, and can be humans, dwarves, gnomes, or doppelgangers.

Starting equipment

Each Caveperson starts with the following equipment:[1]

  • a +1 club (wielded)
  • a +2 sling (alternate weapon)
  • 10-22 flint stones[2]
  • 18-33 uncursed rocks[2]
  • +0 leather armor

The Caveperson's default starting pet is a little dog called Slasher.

Intrinsics

Cavepeople gain the following intrinsic properties upon reaching the given experience levels:[3]

  • Level 7: speed
  • Level 15: warning

Attributes

The Caveperson's starting attributes are distributed as follows:[4]

Attributes Strength Dexterity Constitution Intelligence Wisdom Charisma Remaining
Minimum attributes 10 7 8 7 7 6 30
Distribution percentages 30% 20% 30% 6% 7% 7%
Mean w/ standard deviation 18/01.61±2.48 13.19±2.16 16.43±1.76 8.90±1.40 9.21±1.49 7.90±1.40

Skills

Cavepeople have the following skills available to them:[5]

Barbarian skills
Max Skills
Basic
  • Weapons: dagger, pick-axe, morning star, unicorn horn
  • Spells: enchantment spells
Skilled
  • Weapons: knife, axe, flail, hammer, polearms, javelin, trident, sling
  • Spells: matter spells
Expert
  • Weapons: club, paddle, mace, quarterstaff, spear, bow, boomerang
Master
  • Combat: bare hands

Cavepeople start with Basic skill in clubs, slings, and bare-handed combat. Their special spell is dig.

Techniques

Cavepeople can learn the disarm technique by reaching Skilled in any weapon, and also gain the following techniques:[6]

Level Technique
1 Primal roar

Special rules

Cavepeople have a 2-square vision radius.[7]

Cavepeople do not suffer any penalty for cannibalism, including the aggravate monster property given from eating domestic canine or feline corpses, and additionally gain a +1 bonus to alignment record each time they consume a corpse or tin of their race.[8]

Cavepeople never get nausea from eating tripe rations.

Rank titles

The status line displays one of the following ranks for the corresponding experience levels:[9]

  • XL 1-2: Troglodyte
  • XL 3-5: Aborigine
  • XL 6-9: Wanderer
  • XL 10-13: Vagrant
  • XL 14-17: Wayfarer
  • XL 18-21: Roamer
  • XL 22-25: Nomad
  • XL 26-29: Rover
  • XL 30: Pioneer

Quest

Main article: Caveman quest

The Caveperson's quest sees them fighting the Chromatic Dragon for The Sceptre of Might, an artifact mace. It has +3 to-hit and deals +5 against monsters of a different alignment from the artifact, and grants magic resistance while carried. Invoking The Sceptre of Might toggles hungerless conflict on or off, and conflict caused by the artifact ends once it leaves the main inventory.

Gods

Main article: Religion

The Caveman pantheon is based on the mythology of Mesopotamia (sometimes known as Babylon).[10] Their first sacrifice gift is Skullcrusher.

  • Lawful: Anu
  • Neutral: Ishtar
  • Chaotic: Anshar

Strategy

A user has suggested improving this page or section as follows:

"Detail to match the layout of other NetHack/SLASH'EM role strategy sections and distinguish it from those."

Cavepeople have a handful of additional benefits compared to their NetHack counterparts. Their natural 2-square vision range makes corridors and dark areas like the Gnomish Mines substantially safer to explore even without infravision. The primal roar technique causes all nearby pets to temporarily grow up (e.g. a kitten becomes a housecat, a dog becomes a large dog, etc.), making it life-saving in the early game and a powerful option later on. Unfortunately, Cavepeople do not possess a multishot bonus for thrown spears due to SLASH'EM being a variant of NetHack 3.4.3, since the multishot bonus was added in a later version—the Sceptre of Might is also much weaker as a long-term main weapon candidate, though it does not need to be wielded for magic resistance and invoking for conflict is still quite useful.

The starting flint stones can be upgraded into luckstones or healthstones, which has the effect of making gnomish Cavepeople far less disadvantageous to play as: once they secure a source of reliable permafood, they can use the race's tinker technique in order to upgrade their flint stones. Cavepeople should try to obtain their first gift Skullcrusher as soon as possible: it has +3 to-hit and deals +10 damage to all monsters, allowing it to hold its own well into the late game. The primal roar technique is also especially strong for enterprising Cavepeople that manage to obtain rare pets such as gnolls or liches.

References

  1. ↑ u_init.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 52
  2. ↑ 2.0 2.1 u_init.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 1051
  3. ↑ attrib.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 39
  4. ↑ role.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 107: Cav attributes and distributions
  5. ↑ u_init.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 1450
  6. ↑ tech.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 90
  7. ↑ u_init.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 1050
  8. ↑ eat.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 509: "You honour the dead."
  9. ↑ role.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 86
  10. ↑ role.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 96

{{tocright}}
In [[SLASH'EM]], the '''Caveman''' or '''Cavewoman''', sometimes referred to as the '''Caveperson''', is one of the [[role]]s from ''[[NetHack]]'' that is available to the [[hero]].

Cavepeople can be of [[lawful]] or [[neutral]] [[alignment]], and can be [[Human (starting race)|humans]], [[Dwarf (starting race)|dwarves]], [[Gnome (starting race)|gnomes]], or [[Doppelganger (starting race)|doppelgangers]].

==Starting equipment==
Each Caveperson starts with the following equipment:{{refsrc|u_init.c|52|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2}}

* a +1 [[club]] ([[wielded]])
* a +2 [[sling]] (alternate weapon)
* 10-22 [[flint stone]]s{{refsrc|u_init.c|1051|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2|name="ammo"}}
* 18-33 uncursed [[rock]]s<ref name="ammo"/>
* +0 [[leather armor]]

The Caveperson's default starting [[pet]] is a [[little dog]] called Slasher.

==Intrinsics==
Cavepeople gain the following intrinsic [[properties]] upon reaching the given [[experience level]]s:{{refsrc|attrib.c|39|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2}}

* Level 7: [[speed]]
* Level 15: [[warning]]

==Attributes==
The Caveperson's starting [[attribute]]s are distributed as follows:{{refsrc|role.c|107|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2|comment=Cav attributes and distributions}}

!| Attributes || [[Strength]] ||  [[Dexterity]] || [[Constitution]] ||[[Intelligence]] || [[Wisdom]] || [[Charisma]] || Remaining
|-

|-
| Distribution percentages   || 30% || 20% || 30% || 6%  || 7%  || 7% || 
|-
| Mean w/ standard deviation || 18/01.61±2.48 || 13.19±2.16 || 16.43±1.76 || 8.90±1.40 || 9.21±1.49 || 7.90±1.40
|}

==Skills==
Cavepeople have the following [[skill]]s available to them:{{refsrc|u_init.c|1450|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2}}
{{Caveman skill table (SLASH'EM)}}

Cavepeople start with ''Basic'' skill in clubs, slings, and bare-handed combat. Their [[special spell]] is {{+ of|dig}}.

==Techniques==
Cavepeople can learn the [[disarm]] [[technique]] by reaching Skilled in any weapon, and also gain the following techniques:{{refsrc|tech.c|90|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2}}

{|class="prettytable"
|'''Level'''

|1
|[[Primal roar]]
|}

==Special rules==
Cavepeople have a 2-square vision radius.{{refsrc|u_init.c|1050|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2}}

Cavepeople do not suffer any penalty for [[cannibalism]], including the [[aggravate monster]] property given from eating [[domestic]] [[canine]] or [[feline]] [[corpse]]s, and additionally gain a +1 bonus to [[alignment record]] each time they consume a [[corpse]] or [[tin]] of their race.{{refsrc|eat.c|509|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2|comment="You honour the dead."}}

Cavepeople never get [[nausea]] from eating [[tripe ration]]s.

==Rank titles==
The [[status line]] displays one of the following ranks for the corresponding experience levels:{{refsrc|role.c|86|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2}}

*XL 1-2: Troglodyte
*XL 3-5: Aborigine
*XL 6-9: Wanderer
*XL 10-13: Vagrant
*XL 14-17: Wayfarer
*XL 18-21: Roamer
*XL 22-25: Nomad
*XL 26-29: Rover
*XL 30: Pioneer

==Quest==
{{main|Caveman quest}}
The Caveperson's [[quest]] sees them fighting the [[Chromatic Dragon]] for [[The Sceptre of Might]], an [[artifact]] [[mace]]. It has +3 [[to-hit]] and deals +5 against monsters of a different [[alignment]] from the artifact, and grants [[magic resistance]] while carried. [[Invoking]] The Sceptre of Might toggles hungerless [[conflict]] on or off, and conflict caused by the artifact ends once it leaves the main inventory.

==Gods==
{{main|Religion}}
The Caveman pantheon is based on [[Wikipedia:Mesopotamian mythology|the mythology of Mesopotamia]] (sometimes known as Babylon).{{refsrc|role.c|96|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2}} Their first [[sacrifice gift]] is [[Skullcrusher]].

* Lawful: [[Anu]]
* Neutral: [[Ishtar]]
* Chaotic: [[Anshar]]

==Strategy==
{{todo|Detail to match the layout of other NetHack/SLASH'EM role strategy sections and distinguish it from those.}}
Cavepeople have a handful of additional benefits compared to their ''NetHack'' counterparts. Their natural 2-square vision range makes corridors and dark areas like the [[Gnomish Mines]] substantially safer to explore even without [[infravision]]. The [[primal roar]] technique causes all nearby [[pet]]s to temporarily [[grow up]] (e.g. a [[kitten]] becomes a [[housecat]], a [[dog]] becomes a [[large dog]], etc.), making it life-saving in the early game and a powerful option later on. Unfortunately, Cavepeople do not possess a [[multishot]] bonus for [[thrown]] [[spear]]s due to SLASH'EM being a variant of [[NetHack 3.4.3]], since the multishot bonus was added in a later version—the Sceptre of Might is also much weaker as a long-term main weapon candidate, though it does not need to be wielded for magic resistance and invoking for conflict is still quite useful.

The starting flint stones can be [[upgraded]] into [[luckstone]]s or [[healthstone]]s, which has the effect of making gnomish Cavepeople far less disadvantageous to play as: once they secure a source of reliable [[permafood]], they can use the race's [[tinker]] technique in order to upgrade their flint stones. Cavepeople should try to obtain their first gift Skullcrusher as soon as possible: it has +3 to-hit and deals +10 damage to all monsters, allowing it to hold its own well into the late game. The primal roar technique is also especially strong for enterprising Cavepeople that manage to obtain rare pets such as [[Gnoll (SLASH'EM)|gnolls]] or [[Lich (monster class)|liches]].

==References==
<references/>
{{slashem-7E7}}
[[Category:SLASH'EM roles]]
